instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.U7201: What is U7201? U7201 is responsible for the 3.3v and 5v power rails on many devices..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.P5VS5_EN: What is P5VS5_EN? P5VS5_EN is a signal that turns on the PP5V_S5 power rail. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.SMC_ON_OFF: What is SMC_ON_OFF? SMC_ONOFF tells the computer that the power button has been pressed..
definitions.PP3V3S5_EN: What is PP3V3S5_EN? PP3V3S5_EN is a typo ofP3V3S5_EN_L which is a signal that enables the power chip responsible for creating PP3V3_S5..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.U4900: What is U4900? This is the System Management Controller(SMC) in older(pre-2013) macbooks.
definitions.PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC: What is PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC? PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC Is a reference voltage for the SMCâ€™s voltage sensors & other sensors..
definitions.PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA: What is PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA? PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA is a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state that powers the SMC that comes from PP3V3_S5. A blown or corroded L4901 inductor behind it can kepe it from working, inductor number will differ depending on your board. .
definitions.SMC_TCK: What is SMC_TCK? SMC_TCK is a signal that must be pulled up to 3.42v in order for the SMC to be in the proper mode to function. Often this is not pulled up because of corrosion or corroded resistors by the SMC. .
definitions.SMC_TDI: What is SMC_TDI? SMC_TDI is a signal that must be pulled up to 3.42v in order for the SMC to be in the proper mode to function. Often this is not pulled up because of corrosion or corroded resistors by the SMC. .
definitions.SMC_TMS: What is SMC_TMS? SMC_TMS is a signal that must be pulled up to 3.42v in order for the SMC to be in the proper mode to function. Often this is not pulled up because of corrosion or corroded resistors by the SMC. .
definitions.SMC_TDO: What is SMC_TDO? SMC_TDO is a signal that must be pulled up to 3.42v in order for the SMC to be in the proper mode to function. Often this is not pulled up because of corrosion or corroded resistors by the SMC. .

threads.title: MacbookPro A 1398---<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A- <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> Missing
threads.message:
Hi
I have an macbook pro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A. It has following signal present:-
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL>
PP18V5DCIN_ISOL
But 5V rails are not present. when i traced the problem then found that on <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> <SIGNAL>P5VS4_EN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>P5VS5_EN</SIGNAL> are not present. But <SIGNAL>PP3V3S5_EN</SIGNAL> shows 2.9V.
Then i found <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is also missing. <SIGNAL>SMS_RESET_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMC_ON_OFF</SIGNAL> are present here. i also tried to have look on <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> but could understand from where to start?
what are the steps i missing?
How can i proceed to solve this and what else i have to check please provide suggestion and guidance.
thanks

threads.title: MacbookPro A 1398---<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A- <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> Missing
threads.message:
Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS?
Post exact <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage.
Be sure to use original 85W charger.

threads.title: MacbookPro A 1398---<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A- <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> Missing
threads.message:
Hi, Extremely sorry for the delayed response.
I am using an original 85W charger. and these are the reading i am getting on that machine.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>-12.32V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>-  2.9V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>-  0V

threads.title: MacbookPro A 1398---<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A- <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> Missing
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> are not present.  I have no clue where to start.

threads.title: MacbookPro A 1398---<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A- <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> Missing
threads.message:
Both voltages are incorrect.
Post diode mode at L7220/60 (red probe at ground).
Also post <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> voltages; pins 23, 12, 13, 22, 29, 21.

Check voltage and diode mode at SCL/SDA lines of battery bus too.

threads.title: MacbookPro A 1398---<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A- <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> Missing
threads.message:
Hi
Diode mode reading for L7220-   .422
and L7260-  .133
<CHIP>U7201</CHIP> Pins

Pin 23- 12.30V
Pin 12-0V
Pin 13-0V
Pin 22-3.3V
Pin 29-0V
Pin 21-0V
and battery SCL- .522, SDA--.523
 what should be the <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> in this board? it is 12.32V now.

threads.title: MacbookPro A 1398---<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A- <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> Missing
threads.message:
12.6V is correct <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>; 12.5V reading is accepted too.

You are missing <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> signal.
Do you get Magsafe light?
Is <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> steady high?

Any history fault available?

threads.title: MacbookPro A 1398---<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A- <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> Missing
threads.message:
Yes, I do get Magsafe light green then goes to orange.
And <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is Steady high --3.3V.
no fault history in this. no liquid split sign noticed. completely clean board.

threads.title: MacbookPro A 1398---<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A- <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> Missing
threads.message:
Looks like SMC issue.
Check voltages and signals for <CHIP>U4900</CHIP> (2 OF 2) block at page 41.

threads.title: MacbookPro A 1398---<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A- <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> Missing
MacbookPro A 1398---<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A- <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> Missing
threads.message:
Try reballing SMC first.
Change it, if <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> still low.

threads.title: MacbookPro A 1398---<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A- <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> Missing
threads.message:
Thanks Vali.
I tried that and it's working now. It was a bad SMC. But there is still some issues. One fan near SMC not working and Backight did work once but not after that. I think i need to reball SMC again.
